## The Problem {background-color="#0f172a"}

<br>

::: columns
::: {.column width="55%"}
**Policy Challenge**

Eviction leads to housing instability, homelessness, and long-term negative health outcomes. It is a **cyclical event** â€” the more evictions in a neighborhood, the higher the chance it continues.

<br>

**Who is Affected?**

-   Low-income renters
-   Rent-burdened households (paying 30%+ on rent)
-   Areas with high unemployment

<br>

**Current Problem:** City response is **reactive** â€” interventions come after evictions are filed, often too late.
:::

::: {.column width="45%"}
![](img/eviction_vs_income.png){height="450"}

[Orange = High evictions + Low income]{style="font-size: 0.8em; color: #94a3b8;"}
:::
:::

------------------------------------------------------------------------

## The Solution {background-color="#0f172a"}

<br>

**What We're Predicting:** Monthly eviction filing counts by census tract

<br>

**How Prediction Helps:**

-   Identify **high-risk tracts before spikes occur**
-   Enable **proactive deployment** of emergency rental assistance
-   Target tenant outreach programs to **prevent evictions** rather than respond to them

<br>

**Better Than Current Practice:**

-   Current: Wait for filings â†’ React
-   Our model: Predict risk â†’ Intervene early â†’ Prevent displacement

------------------------------------------------------------------------

## The Evidence: Exploratory Analysis {background-color="#0f172a"}

::: columns
::: {.column width="50%"}
![](img/monthly_eviction.png){height="420"}
:::

::: {.column width="50%"}
**Major Finding: Moratorium Effect**

Eviction filings stayed near **zero from March 2020 â€“ August 2021** due to:

-   Philadelphia Emergency Housing Protection Act
-   PHA internal moratorium
-   Federal CDC moratorium

<br>

Once protections ended (late August 2021), filings **surged past pre-pandemic levels**.

<br>

[**Takeaway:** Prevention policies work â€” this motivates our predictive approach]{style="color: #f472b6;"}
:::
:::

------------------------------------------------------------------------

## The Evidence: Model Approach {background-color="#0f172a"}

<br>

**Model: Negative Binomial Regression**

-   Appropriate for overdispersed count data
-   Population offset â†’ predicting eviction **rate**, not raw counts
-   70/30 train-test split validation

<br>

**Predictors:**

| Category | Variables |
|:---------|:----------|
| Demographics | % Black, % renter, % family households |
| Economics | Median household income, unemployment rate, weekly wages |
| Housing Costs | Median rent, electricity CPI, food CPI |
| Temporal | Year fixed effects, moratorium indicator, income quantiles |

------------------------------------------------------------------------

## The Evidence: Model Performance {background-color="#0f172a"}

<br>

| Model | Description | Train RMSE | Test RMSE |
|:------|:------------|:-----------|:----------|
| Model 1 | Demographics only | 5.89 | 5.82 |
| Model 2 | + Economic indicators | 5.82 | 5.76 |
| **Model 3** | + Year FE, moratorium, income quantiles | **5.76** | **5.69** |

<br>

**Limitations:**

-   Only captures **formal filings** â€” misses informal displacement
-   Census data has **1â€“2 year lag**
-   Spatial autocorrelation present (Breusch-Pagan test significant)

<br>

**Bias Concerns:** Model may reinforce existing patterns â€” high-risk labels could stigmatize already-marginalized neighborhoods

------------------------------------------------------------------------
